Her PhD work was on augmenting 3D reconstructed models of the bronchial tree with 2D video images acquired during bronchoscopy. Bronchial deformation was modelled based on Active Shape Models (ASM) and a predictive tracking algorithm was incorporated to improve tracking of the endoscopic camera. Her track record includes more than 70 peer-reviewed papers/abstracts/book chapters (25 journals, 4 book chapters) and it has been impactful in the machine learning for healthcare applications, along with medical imaging analysis community as it is reflected by her google scholar h-index 25 and more than 4000 citations. She has received substantial funding from MRC, EPSRC, Royal Society and Academy of Medical Sciences to develop machine learning algorithms to analyse medical images, human motion and neurophysiological data to improve risk prediction and diagnosis of diseases. Furthermore, she investigates machine learning approaches for privacy preservation and digital twins in healthcare. Research interests She is part of the Information, Data & Analysis Section (IDA) section. I lead the Biomedical AI and Imaging Lab which specialises on machine learning approaches to analyse medical images, neuro-physiological signals and human motion. I am also a member of the Computing Technologies for Healthcare theme at the School of Computing Science and the healthcare theme lead and supervisor for EPSRC Centre for Doctoral Training in Diversity led, mission-driven research. I am also coordinating the GWiCS - Glasgow Women in Computing group. My interests include: Medical image computing Statistical machine learning, Human Motion Analysis Neuroimage analysis and Brain Connectivity Deep Learning in Healthcare Applications Clinical Decision Support Systems For more information visit: Google Scholar Personal Webpage Biomedical AI and Imaging Lab GitHub Page Datasets at Open Science Framework News/Events: We are thrilled to announce that our workshop proposal on 'Privacy, Fairness, Accountability and Transparency in Computer Vision' has been officially accepted for presentation at the British Machine Vision Conference (BMVC).
